audio.category: and time and urges us to keep questioning our practice to keep it honest and fresh. This talk was offered on Nov. 29
audio.mp3: day 8 of the 2013 Abhayagiri Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa.\r\n

audio.title: Monastic Retreat 2013: Defining and Balancing the Five Spiritual Faculties
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: After describing the dukkha which leads to more dukkha and the dukkha which leads to a spiritual search
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno defines the five spiritual faculties of faith
audio.user: and discernment as the tools needed for this search. This talk was offered on Nov. 30
audio.youtube_id: day 9 of the 2013 Abhayagiri Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa.\r\n

audio.title: Monastic Retreat 2013: Cultivation: Planting Pāramīs
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Ajahn Ñaniko examines the assertion “I don\'t hate myself” as an antidote to guilt as he outlines the ten pāramīs as a framework for long-term cultivation. This talk was offered on Nov. 30
audio.language: day 9 of the 2013 Abhayagiri Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa.\r\n

audio.title: Monastic Retreat 2013: Questions and Answers 7
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Passano answers questions regarding: 1) difficulties 2) karma 3) Buddha\'s past lives 4) the one who knows 5) water bottles 6) dukkha 7) heavy states 9) consciousness 10) mudita 11) elements 12) questions 13) metta 14) merit 15) cause of suffering 16) joy 17) path and fruit 18) three liberations 19) ashes 20) Manitoba 21) tranquility 22) breath 23) depression 24) stopping meditating 25) consciousness as not self. This Q & A session was offered on Nov. 29
audio.language: day 8 of the 2013 Abhayagiri Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa. The full index of questions and answers is available for download here.

audio.title: Monastic Retreat 2013: Questions and Answers 8
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Passano answers questions regarding: 1) relics 2) service 3) anger 4) whole-body awareness 5) getting off the wheel 6) women\'s ordination 7) ten subjects for frequent recollection 8) speech 9) water element 10) the title Lord 11) getting up 12) jhāna 13) bhāvana 14) irritation 15) no self 16) Ajahn Amaro 17) thoughts 18) “no room” 19) drugs 20) aggregates 21) ignorance. This Q & A session was offered on Nov. 30
audio.language: day 9 of the 2013 Abhayagiri Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa. The full index of questions and answers is available for download here.

audio.title: Monastic Retreat 2013: Refuges and Precepts: A Fundamental Toolkit for Being in the World
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno speaks of the three refuges
audio.language: five precepts
audio.category: and the monastery as resources for living a harmless and beautiful life. Paritta chanting follows the concluding exhortation. This talk was offered on Dec. 1
audio.mp3: day 10 of the 2013 Abhayagiri Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa.\r\n

audio.title: Monastic Retreat 2013: Making Offerings
audio.author: Giving Joy
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno praises giving time
audio.mp3: and giving forgiveness as simple ways to generate happiness and form bonds of warmth. This talk was offered on Dec. 1
audio.status: day 10 of the 2013 Abhayagiri Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat at the Angela Center in Santa Rosa.\r\n

audio.title: The Realm of Perception
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Ajahn Karunadhammo reflects on the benefits and drawbacks of the\r\nfaculty of perception. This talk was offered on December 14

audio.title: Preparing for Retreat
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: Ajahn Jotipālo reflects upon a number of Dhamma themes in\r\npreparation for the upcoming Winter Retreat. This talk was offered on\r\nDecember 17

audio.title: Living with Luang Ta Maha Boowa
audio.author: Ajahn Silaratano
audio.body: Ajahn Dick Silaratano encourages the Abhayagiri community in their practice by describing how he arrived at Luang Ta Maha Boowa\'s monastery and eventually became Luang Ta\'s personal attendant for many years. This talk with questions and answers was offered on June 9
audio.language: 2007 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Cutting Out Attachment to the Body (English only)
audio.author: Ajahn Dtun
audio.body: After telling an anecdote from the day\'s almsround
audio.language: Ajahn Dtun goes on to describe the path to liberation. He emphasizes the importance of keeping precepts and then explains how contemplating the true nature of the body leads to each of the four stages of liberation. This is Ajahn Tejapañño\'s English translation of a talk offered on May 9

audio.title: Where Do We Take Refuge?
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Reflecting\r\non several\r\nrecent illnesses and deaths
audio.language:
Ajahn Karunṇadhammo investigates the
questions: “Where do we take refuge?” and “What would a secure
refuge be like?” This
talk was offered on December
25

audio.title: Train the Heart
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Starting\r\nwith an exploration of traditional chanting
audio.language: Ajahn Ñaniko expounds the Dhamma in both theory and practice. Ajahn Ñaniko encourages us to stock in faith and cultivate our hearts
audio.category: despite any difficulties or doubts we may be encountering. This talk was offered on December 22

audio.title: Hand of Impermanence
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: Ajahn Jotipālo recounts his experience with a recent work project which leads a discussion of life and practice in monastery. This talk was offered on December 28

audio.title: Taking Responsibility for Our View
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nRecently back from Thailand
audio.language:
Ajahn Pasanno reviews fundamental
principals of practice including virtue and Right View–the sorrows
of self-view and the happiness that comes from the freedom from
self-view. This talk was offered on December 31

audio.title: Time To Go Inward
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: As\r\nthe monastic community heads into the Winter Retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Ñaniko covers many aspects of practice that will be useful for the community. This talk was offered on January 4

audio.title: Putting Patience Into Practice
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno provides a long-term perspective on practice while weaving in stories and anecdotes from Thailand. This talk was offered on January 8
audio.language:
2014 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

\r\n

audio.title: Don\'t Hanker After Nothing
audio.author: Ajahn Ahiṃsako
audio.body: Visiting\r\nfrom Amaravati and giving his first talk at Abhayagiri
audio.language:
Ajahn
Ahiṃsako
reflects
on gratitude
audio.mp3:
craving and his fortuitous encounter
with Alex.
This
talk was offered on January 18

audio.title: It Requires Effort
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: On\r\nthe eve of Ajahn Chah\'s Memorial Day
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on his legacy…his last years
audio.category: life at Wat Pah Pong after his death and his practice.\r\nTaking cues from this reflection
audio.mp3: Ajahn Pasanno spurs on the community to put forth the effort and endurance needed for their practice to bear fruit. This talk was offered on January 15

audio.title: Hindrances
audio.author: For Your Consideration
audio.language: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo discusses the practice of mindfulness of mind (3rd tetrad of Ānāpānasati Sutta) and understanding and working with the five hindrances. This talk was offered on January 11

audio.title: Noticing the Gorilla
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno provides guidance in traversing some pitfalls of mediation and developing beneficial qualities of the mind. Where are we taking refuge? Are we being reflective? How do we train our minds for peace and clarity? This talk was offered on January 23
audio.language:
\r\n2014 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

\r\n

audio.title: Mystical Overtones
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: Ajahn Jotipālo tells his accounts of dreams and visions in meditation and segues into a discussion of the limits of conventional attention and rational understanding. This talk was offered on January 25
audio.language:
\r\n2014 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

\r\n

audio.title: Wise Meditation
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

Ajahn Pasanno goes over strategies for\r\nreviewing meditation from the Dhamma vantage point
audio.language: including the use of yoniso manasikārā or wise attention. This talk was offered on January 30

audio.title: Fastest Way to Enlightenment
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nFollowing the death of Iris
audio.language: a long-standing lay supporter
audio.category: Ajahn\r\nÑāniko reflects on life and death
audio.mp3: generosity and selflessness and\r\nbeing realistic about the time and effort it takes for the path of\r\npractice to reach fruition. This talk was offered on February 1

audio.title: Letting Go of the Wheel
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno contemplates dying as an integral part of our practice. Reflecting on death helps incline the mind toward relinquishment and letting go. This talk was offered on February 7
audio.language:
2014 at Abhayagiri\r\nBuddhist Monastery.

\r\n

audio.title: Inner Honesty
audio.author: Ajahn Ahiṃsako
audio.body: In his final instructions to his sangha
audio.language: the Buddha named no\r\nsuccessor
audio.category:
saying that after his passing the Dhamma-Vinaya will be
their teacher. Ajahn Ahiṃsako contemplates the relationship between
these two aspects of the training and how the “inner honesty” of
our precepts becomes the guardian for our growth in dhamma. This talk
was offered on February 8

audio.title: 2014 Winter Retreat Opening Talk
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Leading\r\nthe Abhayagiri community into the 2014 Winter Retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno encourages everybody to return to the basics; namely the noble eight-fold path. He also speaks in regards of Iris Landsberg
audio.category: a long-standing lay\r\nsupporter – her condition and providing support for her during her\r\nfinal days. Note: Iris passed away February 1
audio.mp3: 2014. This\r\ntalk was offered on the morning of January 6

audio.title: An Unentangled Knowing
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: \r\nOn the evening of Magha Puja
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on this holiday\r\ncommemorating a day shortly after the Buddha\'s awakening when\r\n1
audio.category:
250 Arahants spontaneously gathered where the Buddha was living. He
reminds us that rather than hoping for some profound moment to “snap
us into enlightenment” it is by patiently practicing the
fundamentals of attentiveness
audio.mp3: restraint and diligence that we can\r\nfind the “unentangled knowing” of the heightened mind. This talk\r\nwas offered on February 14

audio.title: The Pāramīs in Community
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body:
\r\n

At\r\nthe midway point of the Winter Retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Jotipālo reflects on\r\nthe role of the pāramīs when\r\nliving in community
audio.category: with an emphasis on sacca – truthfulness. He reminds us of the importance of slowing down to examine our projections and our intentions in our interactions with others so we can see the truth of a situation more clearly and act from a place of inner honesty. This talk was offered on February 15

audio.title: Seeds of the Hindrances
audio.author: Seeds of the Dhamma
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on the importance of learning to work with the\r\nmental hindrances. He points out that both the dhamma and the\r\nhindrances
audio.mp3: are expressions of the heart's wish for happiness. But while the hindrances are nurtured by ignorance of the way things really are (avijja) and therefore can only bring a self-interested and unsatisfactory kind of happiness
audio.status: the dhamma is nurtured by loving-kindness (metta)\r\nand so can lead to a true peace and contentment. This talk was\r\noffered on February 22

audio.title: The Anchor of the Body
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on mindfulness of the body as an anchor for\r\nour practice. One who has knowledge of the ocean also has knowledge\r\nof every source that flows into the ocean. In the same way
audio.language:
when we
have awareness immersed in the body our practice can encompass all
the skillful qualities that comprise clear knowing. This talk was
offered on February 28

audio.title: New Year
audio.author: New Life: Life Can Be Improved – Evening Session (1 of 3)
audio.language: In\r\nthis first part of the evening session
audio.category: the host provides a short introduction and Ajahn Pasanno guides the audience with some brief meditation instructions. This talk was offered during the evening of December 16
audio.mp3: 2013 at the Buddhadasa Indapanno Archives (BIA) in Bangkok

audio.title: An Auspicious Day
audio.author: Ajahn Ahiṃsako
audio.body: Reflecting\r\non a verse from the Bhaddekaratta Sutta (MN 131)
audio.language:
Ajahn Ahiṃsako contemplates how to deal with thoughts of past events and future plans in meditation.

"You shouldn't chase after the past
or place expectations on the future.
What is past is left behind.
The future is as yet unreached.
Whatever quality is present
you clearly see right there
audio.status:
that\'s\r\nhow you develop the heart.
Ardently doing
what should be done\r\ntoday
audio.user:
for — who knows? — tomorrow
death.
There is no\r\nbargaining
with Mortality & his mighty horde.
Whoever\r\nlives thus ardently

audio.title: Moving Beyond Our Body
audio.author: Mind
audio.body: moving-beyond-our-body-mind-self
audio.category: As the retreat moves into its final\r\nmonth
audio.mp3: Ajahn Pasanno begins the talk with some guidance on\r\nmeditation. He observes how bodily<span style=\"font-style: normal\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal\">\r\nqualities like breathing
audio.user:
and facial expressions interrelate
with our minds and moods. Ajahn Pasanno then broadens his focus and
reflects how our general attitude interrelates with the mind-body
process. In particular
audio.youtube_id: when we get caught up with identification

audio.title: An Unshakeable Deliverance of Mind
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno begins his talk reflecting on how the eight renunciant precepts help to bring a simplicity to the lives of lay practitioners in the consumer society outside the monastery. From there he shifts into an exploration of how practitioners can create a more rooted stillness in the mind
audio.language: both on the cushion and off
audio.category:
based on
observing the movements of The Eight Worldly Dhammas. In this way we
learn to cultivate a stability that keeps us unshaken no matter which
way these eight “winds” may blow us. This talk was offered on
March 15

audio.title: New Year
audio.author: New Life: Life Can Be Improved – Afternoon Session (1 of 4)
audio.language:
\r\n

In\r\nthis first part of the afternoon session
audio.category: the host provides an introduction of the day's events and a brief biography of Ajahn Passano. Ajahn then gives a talk and includes some reflections on meditation and its purpose and instructions on sitting meditation on the breath. This talk was offered during the afternoon of December 16
audio.mp3: 2013 at the Buddhadasa Indapanno Archives (BIA) in Bangkok

audio.title: New Year
audio.author: New Life: Life Can Be Improved – Afternoon Session (2 of 4)
audio.language: In this second part of the afternoon session
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno provides instruction and background on walking meditation. This talk was offered during the afternoon of December 16
audio.mp3: 2013 at the Buddhadasa Indapanno Archives (BIA) in Bangkok

audio.title: New Year
audio.author: New Life: Life Can Be Improved – Afternoon Session (3 of 4)
audio.language: In this third part of the afternoon session
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno goes over common difficulties during meditation including the five hindrances before leading the group into a round of sitting meditation. This talk was offered during the afternoon of December 16
audio.mp3: 2013 at the Buddhadasa Indapanno Archives (BIA) in Bangkok

audio.title: New Year
audio.author: New Life: Life Can Be Improved – Afternoon Session (4 of 4)
audio.language:
\r\n

In\r\nthe final part of the afternoon session
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno and the group engage in a half hour of questions and answers. This talk was offered during the afternoon of December 16
audio.mp3: 2013 at the Buddhadasa Indapanno Archives (BIA) in Bangkok

audio.title: A Center Not Based on Thought
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nWith the ending of the Winter Retreat ten days away
audio.language:
the impulse of
the mind toward conceptualizing and conceiving will naturally arise.
Ajahn Pasanno encourages the community to use this time to review the
fundamentals of the practice – drawing the mind toward peacefulness
and insight. He begins by emphasizing mindfulness of the body as an
important tool for finding a center that does not rely upon thought
audio.category: \r\nand closes his reflections with a contemplation of the liberating\r\nstate of animita vimokkha
audio.mp3: a clarity of mind distinguished by\r\nsignlessness and desirelessness. This talk was offered on March 22

audio.title: An Offering of Practice
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Reflecting on the “coming together for the sake of separation” nature of a retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Ñāniko encourages the community to\r\ncontinue its mature practice of the past winter months in a talk that\r\ninterweaves the teachings on the Foundations of Mindfulness
audio.mp3: and the Noble Eightfold Path in an organic and inspiring\r\nway. This talk was offered on March 23

audio.title: New Year
audio.author: New Life: Life Can Be Improved – Evening Session (2 of 3)
audio.language: In\r\nthis second part of the evening session
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno offers a reflection on using clarity and mindfulness to cultivate skilful choices that lead to well-being and happiness. Following this
audio.mp3: he receives questions from the session's attendees (starts at around 42 minutes). This talk was offered during the evening of December 16
audio.status: 2013 at the Buddhadasa Indapanno Archives (BIA) in Bangkok

audio.title: New Year
audio.author: New Life: Life Can Be Improved – Evening Session (3 of 3)
audio.language: In\r\nthis last part of the evening session
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno offers a New Year’s Blessing in Thai. This talk was offered during the evening of December 16
audio.mp3: 2013 at the Buddhadasa Indapanno Archives (BIA) in Bangkok

audio.title: Six Principles of Cordiality
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: After contemplating the importance of continuity of dhamma practice while moving out of a retreat setting
audio.language: Ajahn Jotipālo reflects on the Buddha's Six Principles of Cordiality from MN 48
audio.category: the Kosambiya Sutta. In enumerating the various aspects of this\r\nprofound teaching
audio.mp3: he stresses the function of loving-kindness as a cohesive element among a community of practitioners. This talk was offered on March 29

audio.title: Still Flowing Water
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

For\r\nthe final talk of the 2014 Winter Retreat
audio.language:
Ajahn Pasanno reflects on
recurring themes from the daily readings that the community has been
sharing from the teachings of Thai Forest masters. The importance of
relying on the “inner witness
audio.category: ” of understanding non-attachment\r\nnot as disengagement but engaging with the clarity and skill of\r\nnon-ego
audio.mp3: and of learning to tell the difference between the activities\r\nof the heart and the heart itself. Through practice with each of\r\nthese key teachings
audio.status: one can achieve a quality that Luang Por Pasanno\r\npraises
audio.user: that of perspicacity – “the quality of having a ready\r\ninsight into things” – which relates to a\r\nmetaphor of Ajahn Chah\'s
audio.youtube_id:
that of still flowing water. With the
discernment gained from these teachings we can have a stable refuge
amidst the arisings and ceasings that make up our world. <span style="font-style: normal"><span style="font-weight: normal">This
talk was offered on March 30

audio.title: The Urge to Merge
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Having recently returned from two and a half months of travel and practice in Sri Lanka with Ajahn Yatiko
audio.language: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo relates an experience of becoming\r\nentangled with unskillful mind states during a period when he and\r\nAjahn Yatiko were separated for an unexpected length of time. Later
audio.category: \r\nin practicing to work on this mental obstruction of anxiety
audio.mp3: he\r\nencountered a teaching of Ajahn Chah’s
audio.status: an instruction to practice\r\nwalking meditation “until the mind separates from the thoughts.”\r\nFrom this place
audio.youtube_id: one can break the\r\n“urge to merge” with habitual kammic patterns of mind

audio.title: The Tracks of Kamma
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno reflects upon the long-lasting nature of kamma (the results of intentional action) using Ajahn Chah's simile of the tracks on an oxcart and emphasizes how long-lasting well-being depends upon clearly understanding our present actions. This talk was offered on April 7

audio.title: In the Middle About That
audio.author: Ajahn Punnadhammo
audio.body: \r\nVisiting monk Ajahn\r\nPunnadhammo talks about the importance of upekkhā
audio.language: the spiritual quality of equanimity. He reflects on how this critical mind state appears in many aspects of the Buddha's teachings – as the final of the Seven Factors of Enlightenment (Bojjhaṅgās)
audio.category: \r\nas the last of the Ten Perfections (Pāramitās)
audio.mp3: \r\nas the culmination\r\nof the Four Divine Abodes (Brahmavihāras)
audio.status: as the most refined form of neither-pleasant-nor-unpleasant feeling (vedanā)
audio.user: and as the ultimate quality of the fourth jhāna
audio.youtube_id: where it becomes the jumping-off point for developing insight (vipassana). At this level

audio.title: Not Why
audio.author: But How
audio.language: The evening before a memorial service for cherished Upāsikā Iris Landsberg
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on the nature of suffering with regard to our feelings around mortality. He reminds us that the Buddha discouraged questions of “why” we live and die and experience suffering
audio.status: taught “how” to live and die and work with our suffering states. This approach leads us away from an attachment to self and towards compassion and loving-kindness for others. This talk was offered on April 19

audio.title: Suffering Is Heavy
audio.author: The Dhamma Is Light
audio.language:
\r\n

As\r\nhe begins a period of retreat at Abhayagiri
audio.mp3: Abbot of\r\nthe Pacific Hermitage in Washington state
audio.status: reflects on his early\r\nmonastic days in Thailand training under Ajahn Pasanno
audio.user:
then shares
some thoughts about qualities of the dhamma that continue to inspire
him. In particular he talks of his experiencing the dhamma as having
a feeling of lightness
audio.youtube_id: as opposed to the heaviness of suffering. He\r\nalso remarks on the completeness of the dhamma as a teaching

audio.title: It\'s Not the Thought That Counts
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Relishing that afternoon's Upāsaka Work Day experience
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on how working with the body can help keep the mind uncomplicated. The awareness of this satisfying state of simplicity can help us in our dhamma practice as we observe the natural tendency of the mind to proliferate over feelings
audio.category: \r\nperceptions and thoughts. Ajahn Pasanno reminds us that it is not the\r\nfeelings
audio.status: and thoughts themselves that create\r\nproblems
audio.user: but this tendency\r\ntoward becoming entangled in them
audio.youtube_id: a state the Buddha called papañca.\r\nThis\r\ntalk was offered on April 26

audio.title: Gratitude and Forgiveness
audio.author: Ajahn Ahiṃsako
audio.body: Drawing\r\nfrom a BBC World Service podcast regarding the Sikh doctor beaten in Harlem who forgave his assailants\r\ntwo days later
audio.language: Ajahn Ahiṁsako reflects upon the connection between\r\ngratitude and forgiveness. This\r\ntalk was offered on April 30

audio.title: The Liberating Lens
audio.author: Ajahn Sudanto
audio.body: At\r\nthe beginning of a year-long sabbatical
audio.language:
Ajahn Sudanto reflects on
the first four years of Pacific Hermitage and his aspiration to use
eight months of solitary retreat to perceive
dukkha in
a direct and profound way through
the liberating lens of the Four Noble Truths. This
talk was offered on April 22

audio.title: Words of Comfort and Consolation for Mothers
audio.author: Ajahn Jayasaro
audio.body: Mother's Day Special: remastered internet-debut of a talk by Ajahn Jayasaro from a bhikkhu ordination at Abhayagiri. Ajahn Jayasaro gives encouragement for “simply living the life of a monk very humbly and quietly” and kindly offers some words of consolation for mothers of monks everywhere.
audio.language: English

audio.title: Transitioning to Walking
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno gives a brief explanation of the role of walking meditation in developing continuity of awareness.
audio.language: English

audio.title: A Working Hypothesis for Rebirth
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Many Western practitioners find it difficult to believe in the\r\nconcept of rebirth
audio.language: and while the Buddha discouraged people from\r\naccepting any teaching blindly
audio.category:
Ajahn Karuṇadhammo tell us that the
Buddha encourages us to hold the concept of rebirth as a working
hypothesis. Looking at rebirth in this way has strong ramifications
for how we see the rest of the dhamma
audio.status: and can be very beneficial to ones life here and now. This\r\ntalk was offered on May 3

audio.title: Ballet and Becoming
audio.author: Ajahn Ahiṃsako
audio.body: Ajahn Ahimsako reflects on trying to get a handle on bhava-tanha – “the craving for identification with some type of becoming” - noting how frequently
audio.language: even in daily life
audio.category: we “die” and are “re-born\'.” As an example
audio.mp3: he relates his own experience of working in the ballet industry and how his mind took to promotions and thoughts of demotion. This talk was offered on May 7

audio.title: Upasika Day - Death and Dying (Part 1)
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno explores both the practical and social aspects of working with death and dying. During this first session Ajahn Pasanno draws on a number of discourses of the Buddha and also includes in his reflections such topics as helping others die peacefully
audio.language: writing\r\nan advanced health care directive
audio.category: and the dedication of merit for\r\nthose who have already passed away.This session took place on \r\nUpasika Day April 12

audio.title: Upasika Day - Death and Dying (Part 2)
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Various participants ask questions and share their experiences\r\nworking with death and dying. In particular
audio.language:
Ajahn Yatiko and
Upasikas Debbie Stamp and Jeanie Daskais share their recent
experiences in relating to close family members in the final stages
of life. This session took place on Upasika Day April 12

audio.title: The Homage of Practice
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: On the evening of Visakha Puja
audio.language: \r\nthe full moon day of May in which the birth
audio.mp3: and the\r\npassing away into parinibbāna of the Buddha\r\nare celebrated
audio.status: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on the act of patipatti-puja.\r\nIn addition to the material homage (amisa-puja)\r\nwe pay on this day
audio.user: through circumambulation of the Buddha statue\r\nwith candles

audio.title: Faith and Inspiration
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: As Visakha Puja approaches Ajahn Karuṇadhammo reflects on the inspiration he draws from the three events this important Buddhist holiday celebrates – the birth
audio.language: the awakening
audio.category:
and the
death of the Buddha. He reminds us that although it may be impossible
to know for sure that what has been handed down to us over the years
regarding these three occasions is “true
audio.mp3: ” if we allow ourselves\r\nto contemplate these teachings from the emotional side of the mind we\r\nmay find
audio.user: a faith in the\r\npractice that transcends the analytical side. This talk was offered\r\non May 10

audio.title: Guided Meditation
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nAjahn Pasanno offers meditation instruction to a large varied group
audio.language:
assembled for the ordinations of Anāgārikas Doug and John and the
elevation of Anāgārika Anthony to Sāmaṇera Khantiko at
Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery on May 17

audio.title: Two Short Talks on Going Forth
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: On the occasion of the ordinations of Anāgārikas Doug and John and the elevation of Anāgārika Anthony to Sāmaṇera Khantiko
audio.language: Ajahn\r\nPasanno speaks of the value of the refuges and precepts in the\r\ntraining for monastic life. These talks were offered on May 17

audio.title: The World is a Small Thing
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Drawing on the Buddha\'s teaching that the world is the six sense bases
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno urges us to learn how to make big problems into small things. He quotes Ajahn Chah: “Sounds don\'t come in and disturb you; you\'re going out and disturbing the sound.” This talk was offered on May 21

audio.title: That Uncertain Element
audio.author: Ajahn Ahiṃsako
audio.body: Ajahn\r\nAhiṃsako tells of a\r\nthree-day tudong
audio.language: a spiritual pilgrimage he recently returned from with Tan Ṭhitapañño. During their 75-mile walk from Fort Bragg to Cloverdale with just alms bowls
audio.status: the Ajahn\r\ncontemplated “that uncertain element” of monastic practice –\r\nthat sense of the scaffolding of life being taken away
audio.user: leaving you\r\nwith only with the dhamma and the vinaya to rely on as you encounter\r\nphysical pain and the self-created suffering that brings on. Yet
audio.youtube_id: between the power of the practice and the many kind acts of strangers and the community

audio.title: The Artist\'s Way
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: Ajahn Jotipālo describes his spiritual relationship with Father Damian of nearby Mount Tabor Christian Monastery
audio.language:
in particular the connection they have through their
shared background in art. This leads into a contemplation on the ways
that learning to be an artist can correlate with learning to live as
a Buddhist in community
audio.category: and on whether it might be possible to use art to teach dhamma. This talk was offered on May 31

audio.title: The Artist\'s Way - Part 2
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: Continuing his contemplation on ways to use art to practice the dhamma
audio.language: Ajahn Jotipālo reflects on a specific project he hopes to\r\nembark on – creating prayer flags based on the Metta Sutta. As he\r\ndescribes preparing for the project
audio.category:
Ajahn Jotipālo reveals that
working with this teaching of loving-kindness in such a detailed way
has led him to a deeper contemplation of it. This talk was offered on
June 7

audio.title: Last Novice Standing
audio.author: Ajahn Preecha
audio.body: Visiting Abhayagiri from Wat Santacittarama in Italy where he has been in residence for two decades
audio.language: Ajahn Preecha talks about his\r\nearly training in Thailand from the age of 12. Although he took\r\nAnāgārika ordination with a group of friends
audio.category: by the end of the\r\ntraining he was the only one who did not disrobe. He was then\r\nassigned to be Ajahn Chah\'s personal assistant
audio.user: he learned profound dhamma lessons by example from the venerable master. Ajahn Preecha also shares his helpful teaching of “The Four “F”s – his unique way of looking at the trainings of sīla

audio.title: Upasika Day - Thai Forest Tradition (Part 1)
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno begins this Upasika Day on the topic of the Thai Forest Tradition by providing background information and answering general questions and then starts with a reading by the founder of the Thai Forest Tradition
audio.language: Ajahn Mun.

audio.title: Upasika Day - Thai Forest Tradition (Part 2)
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: The second session of the Thai Forest tradition continues with readings from the Ajahn Liem
audio.language: the successor to Ajahn Chah as abbot of the main monastery in Thailand
audio.mp3: there are brief excerpts from the monk who wanted to disrobe as well as a final reading from Ajahn Chah.

audio.title: On Feeling Righteous
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: Ajahn Amaro describes the trap of anger and self-righteousness. This talk was originally given on September 15
audio.language: 2013 at Amaravati Monastery and replayed May 28

audio.title: Bhavana-Cultivating the Ground of Practice
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: The Pali word bhāvanā has been translated several ways. Offering a teaching on the fundamentals of meditation practice
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno explores the heart of the word when it is being used to mean meditation – the idea of “cultivation.” He discusses how samatha (tranqility) and vipassanā (insight) practices prepare the ground of the mind for the seeds of liberation from suffering. This talk was offered on June 20

audio.title: Harmony in the Larger Saṅghā
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body:
\r\n

At\r\nthe end of May
audio.language: nearly 100 senior western monastics of the Ajahn Chah\r\ntradition
audio.category: in addition to Luang Por Liem and others from Thailand
audio.mp3: converged at the Amaravati Buddhist Monastery for the International Elders’ Meeting. Recently back from the event
audio.status: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo shares some of his experiences and inspirations that he gathered there. A few topics at the meeting were notable
audio.user: \r\nincluding the\r\nAjahn Chah legacy
audio.youtube_id: what it is and how to preserve it

audio.title: Ordination: Becoming or Cessation?
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: \r\nOn the eve of the Sāmaṇera Suhajjo’s bhikkhu ordination
audio.language: Ajahn\r\nKaruṇadhammo reflects on the meaning of undertaking the bhikkhu training. He discusses a\r\nnumber of topics

audio.title: Abhayagiri 2014 Winter Retreat DVD
audio.author: Abhayagiri Sangha
audio.body: This mp3 DVD contains readings by the Abhayagiri Community from twenty-five different Thai Forest teachers with reflections and commentary by Ajahn Pasanno in response to the community\'s questions. The DVD also includes the contents of six previously released mp3 CDs: the 2013 Winter Retreat
audio.language: the 2012 and 2013 Thanksgiving/Monastic Retreats
audio.mp3: and Ānāpānasati and Viriya from the 2005 Winter Retreat. The DVD is available for free distribution by request
audio.status: and the contents are available online (opens in new tab).

audio.title: Ajahn Sumedho Archived Talk:
audio.author: Ajahn Sumedho
audio.body: For the Saturday June 28
audio.language: 2014 evening talk
audio.category: Ajahn Jotipalo played a recording of a talk given by Luang Por Sumedho during an IMS retreat in May
audio.mp3: 1981. The generic name of the talk is \"Morning reflection #7\" and the theme was \"Taking Refuge in Awareness.\" This talk was played in anticipation of Luang Por Sumedho\'s upcoming visit to Abhayagiri.

audio.title: Upasika Day - Thai Forest Tradition (Part 1.5)
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Karunadhammo continues the Upasika Day with a reading from more recent generations including Luangta Maha Boowa and Upasika Kee Nanayon. During the session
audio.language: there also are questions on the themes of meditation and faith.

audio.title: Finding the Balance in Our Practice
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: \r\nIn response to a practitioner\'s question about feeling oppressed by a\r\ncontinual practice of contemplation of the body
audio.language:
Ajahn Pasanno tells
us it is important to recognize that at different times the mind needs
different things. He then teaches a set of four dhamma principles
that the Buddha described as ancient and unrefutable: non-longing
audio.status: and right concentration. This\r\ntalk was offered on June 26

audio.title: Faith vs. Belief
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Upon returning from an inspiring occasion in Oregon – the dedication of a new Dhamma Hall for the Portland Friends of the Dhamma – Ajahn Pasanno discusses a theme that came up frequently among the weekend gathering of monastics and lay people – that of faith. He reminds us that in Buddhism faith is not a belief system made up of views that inevitably lead to conflict with opposing views. Instead
audio.language: faith is the ability to hold aside one\'s deeply\r\nengrained views as well as one\'s skepticism of views
audio.category: and simply\r\napply oneself with discernment and conviction to the dhamma. This\r\ntalk was offered on July 4

audio.title: Shelter Only for One Night
audio.author: Ajahn Preecha
audio.body: \r\nThe evening before his return to Italy
audio.language: Ajahn Preecha takes his leave\r\nof the Abhayagiri sangha and lay assembly with a brief ceremony of\r\nasking for and giving forgiveness for any unskillful actions of body
audio.mp3: and mind. The sangha and lay assembly reply in kind. Ajahn\r\nPreecha then gives a short talk on our real home
audio.status: the true refuge –\r\nthe dhamma – reminding us that this life is a shelter only\r\nfor one night. This ceremony and talk were offered on July 5

audio.title: A Perfect Teaching
audio.author: Ajahn Sumedho
audio.body: \r\nOn the evening of Asalha Puja
audio.language: the full moon of July when the\r\nBuddha\'s first sermon
audio.youtube_id:
gives a
clear and comprehensive talk on the subject of this sutta – The
Four Noble Truths. Luang Por tells us that the brilliance of this
discourse

audio.title: Uncomplicated
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on the transformational teaching given to Ajahn Chah by Ajahn Mun – that of being able to learn the difference between the mind that knows
audio.language: citta
audio.category: and the objects\r\nof mind that are known
audio.mp3: ārammaṇa. The ārammaṇa\r\nare natural movements of the mind
audio.status: but the complications of our life come from our identifying with these ārammaṇa as a “self.” Whereas what the Buddha's teachings continually point to is finding refuge in the simple and straightforward quality of citta. This talk was offered on July 12

audio.title: The Protectors of the World
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno explains the value of the Buddha's frequent “apophatic” method of teaching – using negative qualities to build a foundation for wholesome action. In this context
audio.language: Luang Por explores the\r\nfunction of sila (virtue) practice – that of achieving a\r\nquality of non-remorse
audio.category: and its two underlying factors: hiri\r\nand otapa. Traditionally translated
audio.status: as shame\r\n(for moral transgressions) and dread (of the disrespect of others)
audio.user:
a
less culturally-weighted translation comes from Ajahn Sumedho –
self-respect and decorum. Delving into these two factors from this
standpoint
audio.youtube_id: Ajahn Pasanno helps us understand why the Buddha called\r\nthem “The Protectors of the World.” This talk was offered on July\r\n19

audio.title: Wisdom Is Available Every Moment
audio.author: Ajahn Sumedho
audio.body: Speaking before the assembled fourfold Sangha at the City of Ten\r\nThousand Buddhas
audio.language: Ajahn Sumedho describes how he investigated his\r\nmind using the Four Noble Truths during a year-long solitary retreat\r\nas a novice in Thailand in 1966. He goes on to discuss mindfulness
audio.youtube_id:
and Sangha.
Rev. Heng Sure introduces the talk with the story of how Master Hsuan
Hua introduced Ajahn Sumedho to him in 1980. This talk was offered on
July 13

audio.title: From Gratitude to Faith
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Ajahn Ñāniko reflects on the quality of kataññu-katavedi (gratitude)
audio.language: particularly in the context of being alive in a period\r\nwhen the dhamma is flourishing in the west
audio.category: despite the occasional derision experienced by monks when they are outside of the monastery. This leads to an exploration of the various meanings of the monks' robes
audio.status: a\r\ncontemplation of desire and clinging
audio.user: and a discussion on the\r\nimportance of balancing faith with wisdom
audio.youtube_id: among other aspects of\r\ndhamma. This talk was offered on July 26

audio.title: The Happiness to Energy Ratio
audio.author: Tan Kaccāna
audio.body:
\r\n

In answer to visitors\' questions from\r\nearlier in the day
audio.language: Tan Kaccāna gives a talk on two topics: what a\r\nlay person can take away with them from a visit to the monastery
audio.category: and\r\nwhy he chose to leave his study of physics to enter the monastery.\r\nFor the first question
audio.mp3: he enumerates four great gifts one can carry\r\nwith them from the monastery. For the second question
audio.status: he shares his\r\ntheory on the interesting relationship between happiness and energy\r\nconsumption in the sensual world. This talk was offered on August 2
audio.user: \r\n2014 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery. Editor\'s note: US per capita energy use increased by only a factor of 1.46 between 1949 and 2011
audio.youtube_id:
not the factor of 3 that Tan Kaccāna recalls in this talk.

\r\n\r\n

audio.title: The Artist\'s Way - Part 3
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: Continuing his contemplations on the relationship between art and spiritual practice
audio.language:
Ajahn Jotipālo compares the attention to detail
required in creating a piece of art to the highly detailed forms of
the monastic training. He then reflects on the role of tradition in
both art-making and spiritual practice
audio.category: and concludes with an\r\nexploration of the meditative quality of his current work in icon\r\npainting. This talk was offered on August 3

audio.title: A Rhythm of Nature
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: With part of the community in seclusion on personal retreats for the Vassa
audio.language:
Ajahn Pasanno reflects on the importance of using this
period to focus on one's meditation practice. In this talk he
emphasizes the Buddha's basic teaching of mindfulness of breathing
and reminds us that the breath connects us to a rhythm of nature
audio.category:
where normally our habit is to look to our personality for answers.
Through awareness of our breath we have the ability to achieve the
higher level of concentration
audio.status: which Ajahn Pasanno\r\nexplains has four functions on the path to releasing us from\r\nsuffering. This talk was offered on August 9

audio.title: The Place of Refuge
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Beginning with a bit of Hawaiian history
audio.language: Ajahn Ñaniko likens our\r\npractice to a desperate run from the Lord of Death towards the refuge\r\nof Buddha
audio.mp3: and Sangha. He goes on to describe how the daily\r\ncustoms and practices at the physical refuge of Abhayagiri Monastery\r\nlead towards liberation. This talk was offered on August 10

audio.title: Wise Attention (Yoniso Manasikāra)
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: The Buddha called yoniso manasikāra – usually translated as “wise attention” – one of the main qualities that is a harbinger of the arising of the path leading to the cessation of suffering. Ajahn Pasanno gives a clear
audio.language: detailed teaching on the\r\nmethods of practicing with this important tool for working with\r\nunskillful patterns of the mind. This talk was offered on August 16

audio.title: The Witness of Change
audio.author: Ajahn Viradhammo
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nVisiting from Tisarana Monastery
audio.language: where he is the abbot
audio.category: Ajahn\r\nVīradhammo talks about two kinds of teachings of the Buddha
audio.mp3: those\r\non our social interactions and those on the inner flow of\r\nconsciousness. The teachings on social harmony
audio.status: such as the pāramī\r\nqualities that include generosity

audio.title: Guided Meditation: Enjoying Meditation
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: With a group of teenage practitioners visiting the monastery for the\r\nweekend
audio.language:
Ajahn Pasanno gives a brief meditation instruction
emphasizing that meditation practice need not be a struggle – it can
be enjoyed when approached with simplicity. This instruction was
offered on August 23

audio.title: From the Story to the Music
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nOne of the great values of forest practice
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno tells us
audio.category: \r\nis to show us that wherever we go
audio.mp3:
we are never without our primary
teachers – our own six sense bases. When we turn our mindfulness to
these internal guides we begin to see through the proliferations of
the mind – the “stories” we have created that make up who we
think we are. At this level of discernment
audio.status: it becomes more obvious\r\nthat the word “right” in the steps of the Eightfold Path doesn\'t\r\nmean the opposite of wrong but rather
audio.user: in the musical sense of the\r\nPali word sama

audio.title: Essence
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nReturning from a visit to Ruth Dennison
audio.language: one of the pioneering\r\nBuddhist meditation teachers in America
audio.category:
Ajahn Pasanno reports on her
vitality of spirit despite her advanced age and failing health. She
impresses upon the visiting group from Abhayagiri to remember to not
mistake transient happiness with true inner peace. This leads Ajahn
Pasanno to reflect on our tendency to measure our achievements in the
practice based on our sense of self-identity. But as he began to
understand when his own teacher
audio.user: once all of\r\nthese things we call our self

audio.title: Practicing Outside
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: On the eve of departure for the annual camping trip near Yosemite\r\nValley
audio.language: Ajahn Ñaniko explains the many benefits of practicing\r\noutside in natural solitude. This talk was offered on September 8

audio.title: Concentration and Wisdom
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: In this rich talk on the interrelated factors of concentration and wisdom in Buddhist practice
audio.language:
Ajahn Pasanno reflects on using Right
View as a primary lens to practice through. He emphasizes two
scriptural methods of investigating Right View – observing how
wholesome vs. unwholesome thoughts and actions make us feel
audio.category: and\r\nawareness of the presence of the Five Hindrances. This talk was\r\noffered on September 13

audio.title: The Ordinariness of Enlightenment
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body:
\r\n

People often think of enlightenment
audio.language: or nibbana
audio.category: as an object\r\nto be sought after. Using the pivotal links of Dependent Origination\r\n– the six sense bases
audio.youtube_id:
and clinging –
Ajahn Ñaniko reminds us that the practice of dhamma is the
contemplation of these quite natural aspects of our existence. And
since it is through these mundane mental states that we have come to
be “burning with the fires of suffering

audio.title: Winter Camping
audio.author: Ajahn Sona
audio.body: This talk was offered on October 28
audio.language: 2008 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Mettā and Upekkhā
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nContemplating the many recent activities at the monastery
audio.language:
Ajahn
Jotipālo notes that his mind has been lately turning more and more
to contemplation of the Brahmavihāra (divine mental state) of mettā
– loving-kindness. He then gives a detailed teaching on mettā
meditation from a unique perspective – that of using the
Brahmavihāra of upekkhā – equanimity – as a preliminary
practice to mettā. This talk was offered on September 23

audio.title: Mettā and Forgiveness
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\nContemplating the end of the traditional period of vassa
audio.language: or\r\n“rains retreat
audio.category: ” Ajahn Jotipālo explains the meaning and purpose\r\nof the upcoming monastic ceremony of pavarana
audio.mp3: in which\r\nmembers of the community may make admonishments and/or ask\r\nforgiveness. In this context
audio.status: with the potential for strong feelings\r\nto arise
audio.user:
the Ajahn reflects on his own past experiences of aversion
to the practice of mettā – loving-kindness – and offers a
broad-ranging teaching on alternate ways to approach this powerful
practice. This talk was offered on October 4

audio.title: Not My Circus
audio.author: Not My Monkeys
audio.language: Ajahn Amaro reflects on the natural tendency of the mind to be like a monkey
audio.category: and that one can accept this without identifying with it. In\r\nthis way
audio.mp3: one can avoid expending unskillful effort in practice. He\r\nthen offers several methods for practicing from Right View rather\r\nthan from self-view. This talk was offered on October 11

audio.title: Relinquishment and Harmony
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: \r\nFollowing the Kathina ceremony
audio.language: in which lay supporters offer the\r\nmonastic community gifts for their sustenance and cloth for new\r\nrobes
audio.category:
Ajahn Amaro contemplates another kind of generosity – that
of relinquishment. When we can let go of self-view and all the ways
we identify ourselves as the “normal” ones distinct from the
“foreigners
audio.mp3: ” we can begin to live in harmony with all beings.\r\nThis talk was offered on October 12

audio.title: Pavarana Day 2014 Community Talks
audio.author: Abhayagiri Sangha
audio.body: Pavarana Day is the final day of the 3–month Vassa retreat period. To celebrate the completion of this period of intensive community practice and vinaya study
audio.language: Ajahn Chah would invite each junior monk to give a short Dhamma reflection
audio.category: and this tradition continues to this day. On October 8
audio.status: Ajahn Pasanno drew names from the Dhamma hall bell and asked the chosen community member to speak. 0:00 Ajahn Pasanno – Introduction; 2:35 Tan Kaccāna – Eleven Characteristics (SN 22.122); 18:51 Anagārika John – Out of the Comfort Zone; 33:34 Anagārika Doug – Vitakka and Vicara; 51:43 Tan Kovilo – Good Friends; 1:04:13 Tan Ṭhitapañño – Determinations; 1:11:57 Tan Pamutto – Mindfulness: The Highest Skill; 1:27:40 Sāmaṇera Khantiko – Keeping Things Simple; 1:31:57 Tan Kassapo – Dhammapada Commentary; 1:41:58 Tan Sudhīro – Facing the Defilements; 1:48:40 Beth Steff – Unbounded; 2:03:26 Sāmaṇera Gambhīro – A Plug for Asuba; 2:06:06 Debbie Stamp – Community; 2:13:48 Tan Suhajjo – Simile of the Acrobats (SN 47.19).

audio.title: 2014 Kathina Ceremony
audio.author: Abhayagiri Sangha
audio.body: <span style=\"color: rgb(34
audio.youtube_id: 255);\">This recording begins with Ajahn Pasanno welcoming Ajahn Amaro and the Kathina visitors and explaining the 2

audio.title: Patient Endurance
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Contemplating his two-week personal retreat beginning the following day
audio.language: Ajahn Ñāniko reflects on the inevitable arising of the worldly\r\ndistractions and defilements of saṃsāra. But rather than turn away\r\nfrom these
audio.category: the practice requires us to confront them
audio.mp3: to let\r\nourselves be “hammered” by them. This process of being “forged”\r\nlike a fine sword from a piece of coarse iron
audio.status: requires the quality\r\nof khanti-parami – patient endurance. This talk was offered\r\non August 18

audio.title: Mindfulness of Awkward Feeling
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: On the last night of his visit to Abhayagiri
audio.language: Ajahn Amaro reflects on the way Ajahn Chah used communal life as Dhamma practice. He goes on to wish Ajahn Ñaniko and Tan Pamutto well on their pilgrimage up the California coast and describes how facing uncertainty with mindfulness can develop the wisdom described by Seng T'san: “To live in this realization is to be without anxiety about non-perfection.”

audio.title: Collaborating with the Mind
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: On the opening night of the retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Amaro gives basic practice\r\ninstructions and the retreatants take the three refuges and eight\r\nprecepts. This talk was given on October 15

audio.title: Aware of Body and Breath
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: On the first morning of the retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Amaro gives guidance in\r\nsitting and walking meditation. This talk was given on October 16

audio.title: The Second Arrow
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: Expounding upon the Sallatha Sutta (The Arrow
audio.language: SN\r\n36.6)
audio.category: Ajahn Amaro explains that although human beings cannot\r\nescape physical pain
audio.status: we can evade the second arrow\r\nof mental suffering. This talk was given on October 16

audio.title: Questions and Answers
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: Ajahn Amaro responds to the questions: “Is there a soul?” “Who is the knower?” “Can I open my eyes during meditation?” “Do I have to focus on the breath?” This question and answer session was given on October 16
audio.language: 2014 at Insight Retreat Center.

audio.title: We Leave but the Practice Remains
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: On the final day of the retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Amaro offers reflections\r\nbefore departing for his next teaching engagement in Portland. This\r\ntalk was given on October 17

audio.title: The Ten Essentials
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: After a harrowing hiking experience during his recent camping trip near Yosemite
audio.language: Ajahn Jotipālo consulted a guidebook that listed “The\r\nTen Essentials” for every hike
audio.category:
finding that he had failed to carry
all but two of them. This got him contemplating what the Buddha might
have considered the ten essentials in such a situation. Consulting
one of the Buddha's “guidebooks
audio.mp3: ” The Aṅguttara Nikāya \r\n(sometimes called the Buddha\'s book of lists)
audio.user: the teaching on the “Ten\r\nProtections.” This talk was offered on September 16

audio.title: Patience and Uncertainty
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno reminds us that being patient is the willingness to be\r\nfully present with experience and that uncertainty opens the doorway\r\ninto wisdom. This talk was offered on October 25
audio.language: 2014 at Abhayagiri\r\nBuddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Respectfulness
audio.author: Humility
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.language: respectfulness-humility-contentment-gratitude
audio.mp3: Trying too hard to control the mind can be it's own obstacle. Ajahn Pasanno encourages us to treat the mind with care and respect so that it turns to and delights in the Dhamma. This talk was offered on September 1

audio.title: Upasika Day - Mindfulness of Breathing (Part 1)
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: On the October 26
audio.language: 2014 Upāsika Day
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno describes\r\nmindfulness of breathing as a method to firmly establish the mind and\r\ndevelop insight. During the first half of the day
audio.mp3: he explores the\r\nfirst of the four tetrads of the Ānāpānasati Sutta
audio.status: which connects\r\nbreathing with mindfulness of the body. Ajahn Pasanno goes on to\r\nanswer questions regarding breathing during the dying process
audio.user: what\r\nto do when the breath slows or stops

audio.title: Upasika Day - Mindfulness of Breathing (Part 2)
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Continuing the October 26
audio.language: 2014 Upasika Day
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno explains how to use the meditation word Buddho and counting breaths to steady the mind. He goes on to give instructions on posture and explain the latter three tetrads of the Ānāpānasati Sutta. The talk is followed by questions about the meaning of sati

audio.title: Loving-Kindness and Flow
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: Having just returned from a trip to the midwest for visiting family and for teaching
audio.language: Ajahn Jotipālo relates an interaction with\r\nstudents at a university near his own alma mater
audio.category:
in which he
encountered a familiar tendency to see the world as “us vs. them.”
He then talks about his experience of teaching loving-kindness
(mettā) practice from a perspective of developing an intention of
loving-kindness rather than “sending” it. This leads into a
reflection on a theory of concentration he was introduced to by a
professor he met on his trip – the positive psychology concept of
“flow.” This talk was offered on October 30

audio.title: Circles of Blessing: Our Redwood Tudong
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Shortly after returning to Abhayagiri
audio.language:
Ajahn Ñaniko describes his
adventures on a two-week walking tudong (pilgrimage) from Fort Bragg
to Avenue of the Giants along with Tan Pamutto. Each day it was
completely uncertain who they would meet
audio.status:
and Ajahn Ñaniko recollects encounters with
the many kind people who helped them along the way. Entering into
this “sacred uncertainty” is the spiritual discipline of tudong
and creates the opportunity for unimagined blessings to arise. This
talk was offered on November 6

audio.title: Praise and Blame
audio.author: Tan Kaccāna
audio.body: Tan Kaccāna reflects on how the eight worldly conditions\r\n(pleasure and pain
audio.language: gain and loss
audio.mp3: fame and\r\ndisrepute) blow the mind around and generate suffering. This talk was\r\noffered on November 1

audio.title: Bananas and Monkeys and Cause and Effect
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno reflects on the choice that we have to put into play skillful causes and conditions that will bring favorable results in our lives. He relates this to the cause and effect logic of the teaching on the Four Noble Truths as well as the teaching on kamma
audio.language: and to learning from the\r\nexperts on how to skillfully eat a banana.\r\nThis talk was offered on November 8

audio.title: Natural Practice
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: After completing a two-week solitary retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno reflects\r\non the importance of “practicing Dhamma in accordance with Dhamma.”\r\nThis talk was offered on October 1

audio.title: The Vision Quest of Dhamma
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Taking off from a discussion earlier in the day comparing the Native American tradition of a “vision quest” to the Thai Forest monastic tradition of tudong
audio.language: Ajahn Ñāniko reflects that everything\r\nis preceded by a vision or an intention
audio.category: and that viewing dhamma\r\npractice in this way will help us to “walk in the vision of\r\nrightness.” This talk was offered on October 18

audio.title: Harmony with Right Mindfulness
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: In his first talk\r\nsince returning from the Pacific Hermitage
audio.language:
Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
offers a reflection on right mindfulness and its relation to other
factors of the 8-fold path. In contrast to using mindfulness as an
isolated practice
audio.category: he discusses how all the path factors support each\r\nother to lead to the end of suffering. This talk was offered on November 11

audio.title: Addicted to Extra Baggage
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
Why can't we be
content with what our present experience? Why are our minds so
addicted to mental proliferation or papañca? Ajahn Pasanno offers a
reflection on the habit of compulsively adding to our basic
experience that
audio.language: when not properly understood
audio.category: becomes an extra and\r\nunnecessary layer of suffering. This talk was offered on November 15

audio.title: Seeds from an Ancient Tree
audio.author: Ajahn Amaro
audio.body: The Ho Center for Buddhist Studies at Stanford invited Ajahn Amaro to\r\nspeak about his journey as a Buddhist monk and his experience leading\r\nWestern Buddhist monastic communities. This talk was given at 7:30 pm on October 14
audio.language: \r\n2014 at the Stanford Black Community Services Center.

audio.title: Tudong: Principled Wandering
audio.author: Tan Pamutto
audio.body: A few weeks after returning from his pilgrimage with Ajahn Ñaniko
audio.language: \r\nTan Pamutto reflects upon the nature of tudong
audio.category: the advice Ajahn\r\nPasanno gave before they departed
audio.mp3: and the lessons they learned along\r\nthe way. He emphasizes the protective qualities of recollecting\r\nuncertainty
audio.youtube_id: and sharing\r\nthe blessings of their efforts. This talk was offered on November 21

audio.title: Why Does Abhayagiri Work?
audio.author: Tan Kaccāna
audio.body: While the senior monks are away on the Thanksgiving Retreat
audio.language:
Tan
Kaccāna recommends that each community member reflect upon the
causes of the present well-being and harmony at Abhayagiri Monastery.
He reflects upon how well-designed physical and organizational
structures
audio.mp3: and our shared\r\naspiration to realize the goal of the Buddha\'s teaching contribute to\r\ncommunal harmony. This talk was offered on November 22

audio.title: Questions & Answers With the Dharma Realm Buddhist University
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: A small group from the Dharma Realm Buddhist University (DRBU) located at the City of Ten Thousand Buddhas (CTTB) spent the morning at Abhayagiri. The group included two bhikkshunis as well as a number of resident volunteers at the CTTB. The students are in the DRBU\'s Masters of Arts in Buddhist Classics program. This semester the students have been reading various spiritual biographies including the biographies of the Thai Forest masters Ajahn Mun
audio.language: Ajahn Tate and Ajahn Lee Dhammadharo. The audio is from their question and answer session with Ajahn Pasanno on November 18th

audio.title: All the Possibilities
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Reflecting on\r\nrecent events in the news
audio.language:
Ajahn Karuṇadhammo contemplates the
capacity we each have for the full spectrum of human behavior. He
encourages us to realize how fortunate we are to have found the Buddha's
path
audio.category: with its moral precepts (sila) and its teachings of\r\nheedfulness (appamada)
audio.status: and concern (otapa). But he also reminds us to hold compassion towards those who have deluded themselves into justifying their unskillful actions. This talk was offered on December 20

audio.title: Notes On Dhamma
audio.author: Tan Kaccāna
audio.body: Tan Kaccāna expounds on the structure of the Dhamma and shares how he uses the Four Noble Truths in meditation. This talk was offered on November 29
audio.language: 2014 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Looking After Buffaloes
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Ajahn Ñaniko poses the question: What does it mean to be a practitioner in the west? Can one practice fully
audio.language: let alone achieve\r\nliberation
audio.category:
given our deep-rooted Judeo-Christian views and opinions?
Or can we only hope to practice well enough to be reborn into a human
life in northeastern Thailand as a farmer looking after buffaloes?
This talk was offered on December 6

audio.title: What Would It Be Like...?
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo discusses how during periods of stagnation or even discouragement with dhamma practice one can remind oneself of one's original inspiration for turning to the dhamma – in his own case
audio.language: the potential for transcendence of suffering. One means of\r\ndoing this
audio.mp3: is to contemplate the three characteristics\r\n– impermanence
audio.youtube_id:
“What would it be like to be completely free of the craving for
stability and contentment despite the way things really are?” “What
would it be like to no longer be at the mercy of a sense of self
always needing to be in charge?” This talk was offered on December
13

audio.title: Upasika Day: Personality View in Daily Life
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Ajahn Karunadhammo reads passages from the suttas (MN 2 and MN 44) regarding personality view (sakkāya-ditthi) and describes how personality view manifests in human interactions
audio.language: particularly\r\nsurrounding our roles in our families. This talk was given on the\r\nDecember 7
audio.category: 2014 Upasika Day at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Upasika Day: Personality View - Guided Meditation
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: The Upasika Day continues with Ajahn Karuṇadhammo leading a guided meditation reflecting on different forms of personality view. This guided meditation was offered on the December 7
audio.language: 2014 Upasika Day at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Upasika Day: Personality View - Group Discussion
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: After breaking into small groups to discuss four questions about personality view in relation to families
audio.language:
the
Upasika Day participants reconvene and share what
they learned. This group
discussion was recorded
on the December 7
audio.category: 2014 Upasika Day at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Attraction and Aversion
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language:
serif"><font style="font-size: 12pt" size="3">Ajahn
Ñaniko explores the mind's tendency to desire and aversion and
shares skillful ways to lessen unskillful mental habits. This talk
was offered on December 14

audio.title: Puñña
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno talks about the importance of puñña (merit)
audio.language: and expounds on ten qualities that support puñña; generosity

audio.title: Dust in the Wind
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body:
\r\n

Using\r\nthe lyrics of the 1977 song “Dust in the Wind” as a springboard
audio.language: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo contemplates the depth of suffering experienced by beings through endless rounds of samsara. He encourages the community to take advantage of the upcoming three months of retreat to move away from the surface reactions of the everyday mind that keep us bound to this cycle and to move instead into a deeper level of practice. This talk was offered on December 28

audio.title: Drunken Dhamma
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: In anticipation of preparing the mind for going inwards during the upcoming Winter Retreat
audio.language: Ajahn Ñāniko stresses a Right View of the practice as a planting of seeds of wholesome causes and conditions rather than as an effort to create pleasant circumstances for ourselves. He cites the teacher Luang Por Waen as referring to those who dwell in the past or strive for future benefit as practicing “drunken dhamma.” This talk was offered on December 27

audio.title: 2014 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat Entire
audio.author: Abhayagiri Sangha
audio.body: This is a 586 MB zip file of the 29 talks given by Ajahn Pasanno
audio.language: Ajahn Karunadhammo
audio.mp3: and Debbie Stamp at the 2014 Thanksgiving Monastic Retreat in Santa Rosa
audio.status: California from November 21 to November 30. The zip file contents are available for online browsing (opens in new tab) and can be requested on CD.

audio.title: Root of Happiness
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Looking to start the new year in a wholesome way
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno\r\nexplores the causes of happiness and well being. This talk was\r\noffered on December 31

audio.title: A Spiritual Journey
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body:
\r\n

Every\r\nliving being is on a spiritual journey
audio.language: Ajahn Ñāniko tells us. Using powerful similes and metaphors
audio.user: ” and “the\r\ntrue mother and father of us all
audio.youtube_id: ” he contemplates what being on a spiritual journey means for a Buddhist practitioner. This talk was offered on January 3

audio.title: Still Investigation
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: With the winter retreat only two days\r\naway
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno talks about the opportunity to relinquish various\r\nburdens and go deeply into the four foundations of mindfulness. This\r\ntalk was offered on January 4

audio.title: The Middle Way
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno talks about walking the Noble Eightfold Path with balance. He teaches true balance arises from experience. This talk was offered on January 10
audio.language: 2015 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Four Techniques
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Ajahn Karunadhammo shares an exposition\r\nof four techniques a practitioner should develop; contemplation of\r\nthe unattractive
audio.language: metta
audio.mp3: and contemplation\r\nof impermanence. This talk was offered on January 12

audio.title: The Body of Compassion
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

With recent teachings of the winter\r\nretreat focusing on body contemplation
audio.language:
Ajahn Pasanno reflects on the
usefulness of seeing inherent characteristics of the body – its
unattractiveness and its impermanence – as a means for developing
compassion for oneself and for others. This talk was offered on
January 17

audio.title: Renunciation
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.youtube_id: 255);\">Ajahn Karuṇadhammo talks about the\r\nvarious aspects of relinquishment. This talk was offered on January\r\n19

audio.title: The Goldsmith\'s Apprentice
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Using the Buddha\'s simile of the\r\ngoldsmith\'s apprentice
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno teaches the importance of\r\nfinding the balance of three qualities we can apply to working with\r\nour meditation object – tranquility
audio.mp3: and equanimity. This\r\ntalk was offered on January 24

audio.title: Untying the Knots
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.language: serif\">Ajahn\r\nÑāniko covers a variety of topics including eating one meal per\r\nday
audio.status: and patience. This\r\ntalk was offered on January 27

audio.title: The Uses of Desire
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\">The\r\nBuddha taught that “all phenomena arise out of desire.” As Ajahn\r\nPasanno explains
audio.category: this means that desire isn\'t simply something to be\r\nrid of but is also a tool that we can use in our practice. This talk\r\nwas offered on January 31

audio.title: Investigating the Mind
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.youtube_id: 255);\">Ajahn Karuṇadhammo explains different ways of investigating desire

audio.title: As Simple as the Breath
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\">Ajahn\r\nPasanno contemplates how “something as simple as the breath” can\r\nbe used as a base of exploration into the entire path of sila
audio.mp3: and paññā. This talk was offered on February 7

audio.title: Conjurer\'s Trick
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: <span style=\"color: rgb(34
audio.youtube_id: 255);\">Ajahn Ñāniko talks about sustainable practice and the impermanent nature of phenomena. This talk was offered on February 11

audio.title: The Perils of Self
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language:
serif"><font style="font-size: 12pt" size="3">Ajahn
Pasanno examines the “constellation of unwholesome states” that
can arise when we identify with the five aggregates of clinging as a
“self.” This talk was offered on February 14

audio.title: The Dirt Washer
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo guides us through the Pansadhovaka Sutta in which the Buddha likens the process of refining gold to the process of refining the heart. This talk was offered on February 17
audio.language: 2015 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: A Reflection on Refuge
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\">Inspired\r\nthis evening by the passages in the chanting where the community\r\n“takes refuge” in the Buddha
audio.status: Ajahn\r\nPasanno contemplates the meaning of refuge as a commitment to\r\nskillful awareness and to a life lived without remorse
audio.user: abiding in\r\nthe spiritual principles of the pāramitās.\r\nThis talk was offered on February 21

audio.title: Five Dhammas
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Ajahn Ñāniko analyzes five dhammas which give courage; faith
audio.language: virtue
audio.status: and wisdom. This talk was given on February 25

audio.title: Freedom from Conception
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: <font face=\"Times New Roman
audio.language: serif\">As\r\nthe community continues its exploration of the Buddha\'s teaching on\r\nānāpānasati
audio.mp3:
Ajahn Pasanno contemplates the power of
this teaching to free ourselves from making the mental leap from
perceiving to conceiving. It is with formation of conceptions that we
create a mythology of self and other and of past and future
audio.status: and with awareness one breath at a time we can let conceptions go and find true peace. This talk was offered on February 28

audio.title: Allow the Mind to Be Dhamma
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno talks about cultivation and development of wholesome qualities. This talk was offered on March 7
audio.language: 2015 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Training the Heart
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Ajahn Ñāniko talks about seeing the inner workings of the heart
audio.language: calling everything into question
audio.category: and steering the heart in wholesome directions. This talk was offered on March 12

audio.title: Skillful Dhamma
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Ajahn Pasanno encourages us to carefully investigate the body and mind
audio.language: challenge our assumptions
audio.category: and practice the balanced Dhamma of relaxation and alertness. He teaches
audio.mp3: “Our practice is learning how to pay attention to these ordinary things.” This talk was offered on March 14

audio.title: Wise Practice
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo talks about watching the mind and non-attachment. This talk was offered on March 19
audio.language: 2015 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Rooted in the Body
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: Ajahn Ñāniko teaches that although all four foundations of mindfulness are interrelated
audio.language: mindfulness of the body is the root practice from which the others stem. He offers some creative ways to practice body contemplation and reflects on the critical relationship between mindfulness of the body and gaining insight into not-self. This talk was offered on March 21

audio.title: Five Hindrances
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.body: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo explains what the five hindrances are and how to quiet them. This talk was offered on March 27
audio.language: 2015 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Something More
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\">With\r\nthe three-month winter retreat coming to a close
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno\r\nreflects on the nature of the mind to judge experiences and wonder if\r\nthere could have been something more. But
audio.status:
this is
exactly what saṃsāra is – an endless wandering through a state
of expectation and craving. What is truly important is to be simply
but fully with the experiences – therein lies the path to peace.
This talk was offered on March 28

audio.title: The Benefits of Walking Backwards
audio.author: Ajahn Ñāniko
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\">Ajahn\r\nÑāniko contemplates the benefits of walking backwards
audio.category: something he\r\nhad witnessed Tan Kasappo doing recently on the monastery road up the\r\nmountain. In trying it as a practice for himself
audio.mp3: Ajahn Ñāniko\r\nrecognized it as a powerful metaphor for assessing
audio.user: and aligning oneself with the path while allowing the future to be unknown. He elaborates how in this way one can relax into the moment yet practice with saṃvega – a wholesome sense of urgency for liberation. This talk was offered on April 4

audio.title: The Highest Blessings
audio.author: Ajahn Karuṇadhammo
audio.language:
serif"><font style="font-size: 12pt" size="3">Ajahn
Karuṇadhammo reflects on the Mangala Sutta – the Buddha's
teaching on “The Highest Blessings” – and how it reflects and
supports the Noble Eightfold Path. This talk was offered on April 11
audio.category:
2015 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.


Mangala Sutta (The Highest Blessings)


Thus have I heard that the Blessed One
Was staying at Savatthi
audio.mp3:
Residing at the Jeta’s Grove
In Anathapindika’s Park.
Then in the dark of the night
audio.status:
a radiant deva
Illuminated all\r\nJeta’s Grove
She bowed down low\r\nbefore the Blessed One
audio.user:
Then standing to one side she said:


“Devas are concerned for happiness
And ever long for peace;
The same is true for humankind.
What

audio.title: Breath and the Path
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: <font face=\"Times New Roman
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\">Reflecting\r\nthat the Buddha\'s teachings were not just a meditation technique but\r\na bringing together of the eightfold path factors of sila (virtue)
audio.status: serif\">aññā

audio.title: Mississippi Revisited
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: Ten years after Ajahn Jotipālo\'s original journey up the Mississippi River
audio.language: Ajahn Pasanno and Ajahn Jotipālo were invited to the Flowering Lotus Meditation Center in Magnolia
audio.category: Mississippi. Ajahn Jotipālo describes several unexpected encounters during their six day visit and reflects on their experience. This talk was offered on April 17

audio.title: Contentment and Gratitude
audio.author: Ajahn Sudanto
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\"><span style=\"font-style: normal\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal\">Ajahn\r\nSudanto contemplates the habitual nature of the mind to obsess over\r\nthe way things aren\'t
audio.category: and teaches how nurturing contentment and\r\ngratitude can lead to a more skillful way to be with the way things\r\nreally are
audio.mp3: serif\">.\r\n
audio.status: serif\">This\r\ntalk was offered on April
audio.user: serif\">25
audio.youtube_id: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\"><span style=\"font-style: normal\"><span style=\"font-weight: normal\">

audio.title: Returning the Light
audio.author: Ajahn Ahiṃsako
audio.body: \r\n
