audio.title: Paths of Gentle Awareness
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\"><em><span style=\"font-style: normal\">Having\r\nconsidered starting his evening reflection with ten minutes of\r\nsilence to cause us to watch the reactions of our minds
audio.category: Ajahn Jotipālo instead leads us onto some paths of gentler awareness. He first delineates the path of concentration meditation with its destination of states of jhana leading to equanimity. Then he shows us the path of contemplation meditation with its destination of dispassion
audio.mp3: also leading to equanimity. This talk was offered on August 27
audio.status:
2016\r\nat Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

\r\n

\r\n

audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno begins his Saturday night reflection with an explanation of the purpose of chanting namo tassa bhagavato arahato samma sambuddhassa before a talk. In recollecting the primary qualities of the Buddha – wisdom
audio.status: and compassion – the teacher is\r\nsetting an intention for all of us to cultivate these qualities in\r\nbalance
audio.user: a very different preface than saying
audio.youtube_id: “I will now convey information you need.” This de-emphasis of the self in teaching leads into contemplations on ways the self gets in the way of one's own liberation

audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\"><em><span style=\"font-style: normal\">Picking\r\nup from the previous evening\'s reflections
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno teaches the\r\npath of sense restraint
audio.mp3: which is not about denying or pushing away sense impressions but instead about using them skillfully to nourish and nurture our wisdom and well-being. This talk was offered on September 10
audio.status: 2016 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Turning Toward the Beautiful
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\n

audio.category: and noticing the results this brings. He stresses not pushing away the negative but instead turning toward the positive
audio.mp3: \r\nand makes an interesting reverse correlation of\r\nthe three core hindrances of greed
audio.user: and delusion with\r\nthe Buddha\'s reference to three personality types: faith-based

audio.title: Beasts of Burden
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\"><em><span style=\"font-style: normal\">Ajahn\r\nPasanno reflects on the human tendency to pick up the conditions of\r\nour five khandas – form
audio.user: and consciousness – as burdens. But the Buddha taught that if we make the choice to pick up these conditions of the khandas as objects of investigation and contemplation they can become catalysts for relinquishment

audio.title: No Anchor
audio.author: No Boundaries
audio.language:
\r\n

\r\n
audio.category: serif">Ajahn Pasanno reflects on the tendency of the mind to latch onto memories from the past or projections of the future as a way to keep a sense of self going
audio.mp3: to the point that the alternative – stillness and peace – can become something we actually fear. This is where mindfulness of the body can be a powerful tool for setting an anchor to establish boundaries for the mind. Not to banish thought but to find a balance between our attraction to past and future and the true freedom of the present moment. This talk was offered on October 1
audio.status:
2016\r\nat Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

\r\n

audio.title: Speaking in Tune
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\n
audio.language: serif\">Following\r\nthe Upasika Day teachings on the subject of Right Speech
audio.category: Ajahn Pasanno offers a reflection on the deeper meanings of both “right” and “speech” from the Buddha's standpoint. He teaches that the concepts of vitakka and vicara – initial thought and sustained thought – usually thought of as aspects of silent meditation
audio.mp3: are an important part of\r\nhuman communication
audio.status: and that the word translated as “right” means something more akin to music being in tune. This talk was offered on October 8
audio.user: 2016 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: Catching It at the Feeling
audio.author: Ajahn Jotipālo
audio.body: \r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\"><em><span style=\"font-style: normal\">Continuing\r\na theme from the Upasika Day teachings the day before
audio.category: Ajahn\r\nJotipālo contemplates\r\nthe somewhat mysterious word from the Buddha\'s time
audio.status: serif">ñca. Traditionally translated as “mental proliferation” and more recently translated by Thanissaro Bhikkhu as “objectification
audio.user: ” Ajahn Jotipālo reflects on it as a process by which the natural peaceful state of mind is cut off by obstacles of thoughts and mental states that bring us into the realm of “self.” He explores two different angles to come at papa
audio.youtube_id: serif\">ñca\r\n- paying attention\r\nto the resulting actions

audio.title: Where Is the Buddha Now?
audio.author: Ajahn Sona
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\"><em><span style=\"font-style: normal\">Visiting\r\nfrom Birken Monastery in British Columbia
audio.category: Ajahn Sona recollects\r\nan encounter with an elderly Chinese monk\r\nwho had asked him
audio.mp3: “Where is the Buddha now?” Reflecting\r\non his answer at the\r\ntime and the answer he later wished he\'d given
audio.status: Ajahn Sona speaks on the importance of using the concrete structures of practice – from buildings and statues to robes and rituals – to find something more abstract but more fulfilling – the dhamma. He elaborates that for this process one must move from beliefs to conviction to experience
audio.user: and he uses the beautifully human story of the Buddha's first six years of searching to illustrate how this is a process of finding our way back to our humanity. This talk was offered on October 22
audio.youtube_id: 2016 at Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: The Kamma of Fear
audio.author: Tan Kaccāna
audio.body:
\r\n

\r\n
audio.language: serif\"><font style=\"font-size: 12pt\" size=\"3\"><em><span style=\"font-style: normal\">Reflecting\r\non his recent experience with a Seattle meditation group days after\r\nthe American presidential election
audio.category: Tan Kaccāna contemplates fear from a Buddhist perspective. He points out that there are skillful states of fear and discusses two – otapa (fear of the results of unskillful actions that inspires sila) and samvega (a fear of dukkha that inspires ones practice). But he also reflects how unskillful fear born of uncertainty about the future can lead us to abandon refuge in worldly things and to seek refuge in dhamma. This talk was offered on November 19

2016\r\nat Abhayagiri Buddhist Monastery.

audio.title: The Happy Mind Is Easily Concentrated
audio.author: Ajahn Pasanno
audio.body: Drawing\r\na connection between the settling of the mind and the winter season
audio.language: \r\nLuang Por gives us an important reminder: to allow the mind the\r\nsettle into a happy state of mind
audio.category: we musn\'t let the mind follow\r\nunwholesome habits which lead us in the opposite direction. Instead
audio.mp3: \r\nwe should \"get a feeling\" for the wholesome (kusala) and\r\nunwholesome (akusala)
audio.status:
so that we can build the necessary foundation
for a wholesome sense of peace and happiness; this is a happiness
which is "born of seclusion" from unwholesome states. This

audio.language: Ajahn Karunadhammo shows how we can employ intention and attention to gradually but radically change our perception of the world. He continues with a guided reflection which develops our capacity to change our perceptions of people toward whom we feel anger or aversion. This talk was offered on the daylong retreat “The Colors of Experience” at Spirit Rock Mediation Center on November 13

audio.title: Stories from the 2001 Ajahn Chah Conference
audio.author: Ajahn Chah
audio.body: \r\nIn\r\nApril 2001
audio.language: a number of Ajahn Chah\'s senior Western disciples and\r\nmany others his life had touched gathered in Portola Valley
audio.category:
California to recollect their beloved teacher. Tan Kaccāna selected
five short recollections that contain both classic and little-known
stories of Ajahn Chah and
replayed them at
Abhayagiri on December 14
audio.mp3: 2016. The recording concludes with Ajahn Chah's teaching “Living with the Cobra".” More audio from the 2001 conference is available on the Abhayagiri 20th Anniversary website.
audio.youtube_id: 2016-12-14 Ajahn Chah Stories from the 2001 Conference.mp3
